author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Miso, Butter, Salmon
description: Chan chan yaki takes three superb ingredients and adds sautéed veggies and a glug of sake for a fast, filling, salty-sweet dinner.
content: When I pitched this recipe for chan chan yaki — miso butter salmon — to Genevieve Ko, New York Times Cooking’s recipe wizard (and deputy editor), she lit up. “Three of my favorite things: miso, butter and salmon!” she said. And that’s how I feel, too, about this recipe that I adapted from one by Marc Matsumoto. (Marc’s a Tokyo-based food personality who, along with running his recipe blog, No Recipes, is a co-host of the charming “Bento Expo” show on NHK, Japan’s public broadcaster.) An easy dinner built on three flavorful, über-umami ingredients — what’s not to love?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Vault
description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Paris, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
content: For two weeks every four years, women’s gymnastics is one of the biggest sports in the world. The rest of the time, those of us watching are kind of a niche group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Diamond
title: Sophia Roe’s Charm Earring
description: The James Beard Award-winning chef is at her best when her bangs and eyeliner are right and her earrings are asymmetrical.
content: There are certain rules that Sophia Roe can’t seem to shake from her years working in restaurants: short nails, no nail polish, a separate sink to wash her hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: The Amiable Attack Dog From Kentucky Who Could Join the Harris Ticket
description: Andy Beshear, the Democratic governor of a deep-red state, is an intriguing Southern contender to become Kamala Harris’s running mate. He’s already straining to go after JD Vance.
content: A political scion with the most famous last name in Kentucky Democratic politics, Andy Beshear, the affable, aw-shucks governor, is best known around the state for showing up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate LoPresti, Sara Curtis, Wendy Dorr, Diane Wong, Dan Powell and Jon Pareles
title: Lana Del Rey and Quavo Team Up
description: Plus more new music for your weekend.
content: Jon Pareles, the chief pop music critic for The New York Times, recommends an unexpected collaboration, some guaranteed uplift, and more:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra Winther and Michael February
title: How the Ocean Is Liberating for One of South Africa’s Best Surfers
description: Michael February, a boundary-breaking surfer and the first Black South African on the World Surf League Championship Tour, embarks on a transformative journey.
content: I was born in 1993, just as apartheid was ending in South Africa. My father is an avid surfer who introduced me to the sport at a young age, and the freedom he felt in the ocean had a big impact on me. He faced challenges pursuing the sport, since it was historically reserved for white South Africans and beaches were segregated until 1989. But by the time I came around, things were changing. Being able to bring his son to the beach and into the water was something he’d always dreamed of. He’d always have a big smile on his face when we’d go surfing together, and he still does.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: 15-Year-Old Dies in Queens, Likely From ‘Subway Surfing,’ Police Say
description: The teenage boy was found unconscious at a subway station in the Rockaways early Friday evening.
content: A 15-year-old boy was found dead on a roadbed at a subway station in Queens on Friday. The boy, whom officials have not identified, most likely died as a result of so-called subway surfing, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: The Olympics Have Arrived
description: The Games present untold opportunities to geek out on sports you haven’t thought about for several years, or ever.
content: It has been only three years since the last summer Olympics: the 2020 Tokyo Games, you’ll recall, were held in the summer of 2021. Time has been slippery since the pandemic began, anyway, even without reliable milestones moving around. Three years feels simultaneously like an eternity (think of how much has happened in the last three weeks) and a heartbeat (I’ve been just about to check out this playlist of “frat rock” recommended by Bruce Springsteen … for the past three Julys).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: The Big 5-0
description: Paolo Pasco puts solvers (us!) on the podium.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy A. Ruhling
title: How a Drum Line Director Spends Her Sundays
description: Stacy Kovacs, who founded Fogo Azul NYC, totes her drums around the city, fends off her cat and never watches TV.
content: For most of her life, Stacy Kovacs has been following the beat of the drum, which has led her to people and places she never anticipated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: Bullet or Fragment of One Struck Trump’s Ear, F.B.I. Says
description: The explanation was the most definitive to date after the bureau’s director had earlier suggested the former president might have been hit by shrapnel, igniting a political storm.
content: The F.B.I. said on Friday that Donald J. Trump had been struck by a “bullet, whether whole or fragmented into smaller pieces,” providing the most definitive explanation to date about what injured the former president’s ear during an assassination attempt this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Carl Hulse
title: Embattled Democrats Express New Hope With Harris at Top of Ticket
description: Incumbents who had feared President Biden would drag them down to defeat say the electoral environment has improved rapidly since he left the race.
content: Senator Martin Heinrich, a two-term Democrat from New Mexico, was not on anyone’s watch list of incumbents facing serious re-election trouble given the reliable partisan tilt of his state, which has not voted for a Republican for Senate since 2002 or a Republican presidential candidate since 2004.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: A Digital Coin Based on Baby Trump? Yup.
description: One of the wildest, most scam-ridden corners of the cryptocurrency industry — memecoins, which are rooted in internet memes — has roared back.
content: Josh Bailey, a 26-year-old day trader in Austin, Texas, was scrolling through a cryptocurrency group chat last month when he encountered an investment opportunity: a digital currency created in honor of a dog named Billy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Harris Holds First Fund-Raiser as Democrats Rally: ‘We Are the Underdogs’
description: At the event, which her campaign said raised more than $1.4 million, Vice President Kamala Harris deployed a sharpened message against Donald J. Trump and his running mate, JD Vance.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris warned a crowd of supporters on Saturday that former President Donald J. Trump held the advantage in their contest for the White House given the short window until Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Kamala Harris and the Audacity of Desperation
description: With the surge of support for her candidacy, you can sense an effort to overcome divisions on the left and to recover the unity of 2020.
content: Across Donald Trump’s presidency, the American establishment achieved an unprecedented level of ideological unity and conformity — first in opposition to Trump himself, and then in the embrace of progressive ideology, in the “Great Awokening” that reached a crescendo in the hotter months of 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Spoiler Alert: Here’s a Guide to the Cameos in ‘Deadpool & Wolverine’
description: Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are the stars, but they get help from a host of actors you may know from other superhero movies.
content: “Deadpool & Wolverine” expects its audience to have a very good memory. To get the most out of the movie you have to not only be well-versed in the previous films starring the characters of the title — Ryan Reynolds’s foul-mouthed mercenary and Hugh Jackman’s gruff mutant with spiky claws — but you also should be able to recall the last 25 or so years of movies inspired by Marvel comic books. Even the ones that perhaps Marvel would like to forget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diane Harris
title: The 3 Biggest Mistakes You Can Make With Your 401(k)
description: Here is what experts say are the costliest stumbles people make with their retirement savings accounts — and how to get back on course.
content: In a surprising turn, given the usual grim reports about how little most Americans have saved for retirement, there’s been a spate of good news lately about 401(k) investors. Plan participation, contributions and account balances all were at or near record highs in 2023, according to a study last month from Vanguard. And new research from BlackRock shows that, buoyed by a surging stock market, nearly 70 percent of workplace savers now feel they’re on track for retirement — a 12 point jump from last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Newman
title: To Uber, With Love
description: After my autistic son was barred from his favorite app, I sprang into action.
content: This is a happy story about a corporation you probably hate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: What to Know About Kamala Harris’s Foreign Policy Positions
description: Here is what we know about the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee’s views on issues like migration and the wars in Ukraine and Gaza.
content: Hundreds of former Democratic foreign policy leaders this week backed Vice President Kamala Harris in her bid for the White House, vouching for their party’s presumptive nominee despite her limited experience in matters of diplomacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: The French Swimmer Who Is Carrying His Country on His Back
description: Léon Marchand, who has the potential to win medals in four individual events, bears much of the weight of France’s expectations. He is ready, he says, but adds, “it does feel weird.”
content: The French swimmer Léon Marchand understood that he would be his country’s marquee athlete at the Paris Games, and he surely is. Event workers stop him to sneak in selfies. A giant photo of him on the starting blocks adorns a skyscraper. Cameras are trained on him everywhere he goes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Dutch Novels Plumb the Gulf Between Order and Chaos
description: A late-life fantasia; a surviving twin’s breakthrough.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. Sandel
title: How Kamala Harris Can Win
description: She will need a message that reconnects the Democratic Party with the working-class voters it has alienated in recent decades.
content: Kamala Harris has a lot to do in a short time — build a team, choose a running mate, introduce herself to the country. But her most important task is to figure out what this election should be about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Tells Christians ‘You Won’t Have to Vote Anymore’ If He’s Elected
description: Donald Trump, after lamenting that conservative Christians are not “big voters,” urged the religious right to turn out for him “just this time.”
content: In the closing minutes of his speech to a gathering of religious conservatives on Friday night, former President Donald J. Trump told Christians that if they voted him into office in November, they would never need to vote again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Sapna Maheshwari
title: Justice Dept. Defends TikTok Law That Forces App’s Sale or Ban
description: In its first detailed response to a legal challenge, the agency said TikTok’s proposed changes wouldn’t prevent China from using it to collect U.S. users’ data or spread propaganda.
content: The Justice Department argued in a court filing on Friday that TikTok should be required to sell its American operations to resolve national security concerns about its Chinese parent company, ByteDance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Snoop Dogg, NBC’s New Voice of the People
description: The network hired the rapper for an expanded role on its broadcasts of the Summer Games in Paris after posting record-low viewership of the Tokyo competition.
content: Once Snoop Dogg had waded through electrical cords on the floor and ambled his lanky frame around the disorderly equipment in a partially constructed television studio in Paris, he was able to peer out over a balcony overlooking the Eiffel Tower and survey the city he hopes to conquer during the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: How Do You Solve a Problem Like Elon?
description: Linda Yaccarino, the C.E.O. of X, has worked hard to bring back advertisers and fix the platform’s business. But its owner, Elon Musk, is always one whim away from undoing her work.
content: Late last year, Linda Yaccarino reached out to Don Lemon’s agent with an offer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: California School Official Who Embezzled $16.7 Million Gets Nearly 6 Years in Prison
description: Jorge Armando Contreras used his position at a school district in Orange County to fund a luxurious lifestyle, prosecutors said.
content: A former California public school official who embezzled more than $16 million from a school district and used the money to fund a lavish lifestyle was sentenced to nearly six years in prison this week, according to the Justice Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy Tarng
title: A Cross-Country Road Trip, With a Hidden Body in the Back Seat
description: In Soma Mei Sheng Frazier’s debut novel, “Off the Books,” a Chinese American college student chauffeurs a handsome and suspicious client from California to New York.
content: When Mei Brown’s grandfather hands her the keys to a sedan purchased “with the savings from his life as a mechanic,” she sums up her current circumstance succinctly. “Her father had blown his brains out, she’d dropped out of an Ivy League school and her mother hated her. But Laoye had bought her a car.” With it he hands her an opportunity: clients (mostly sex workers) to drive around — and space from the life she’s trying to figure out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
title: Rocket From Lebanon Kills at Least 12 in Israeli-Controlled Golan Heights
description: It was the deadliest single attack from across Israel’s northern border in months of hostilities. Israel blamed Hezbollah, which denied responsibility.
content: A rocket from Lebanon struck a soccer field on Saturday in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, killing at least 12 people, mostly teenagers and children, according to the Israeli military. It was the deadliest single attack from across Israel’s northern border in months of hostilities and raised fears of an escalation in the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: Chinese Swimmer Denies Cheating in First Public Comments on Doping Case
description: Zhang Yufei, one of 23 athletes who tested positive for a banned substance before the last Olympics, said China did not allow doping, and offered a window into the stress the accusations have caused.
content: An Olympic swimming champion who was one of 23 Chinese athletes who tested positive for a banned substance before the last Summer Olympics said on Saturday that she and her teammates had been wrongly accused of doping and insisted that China would never allow any athlete to use performance-enhancing drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: Beyond ‘Bridgerton’: 3 Steamy, Summery New Historical Romances
description: Our columnist on vacation-ready reads.
content: Most historical romance is solidly grounded in what I’ll call textbook history, where many narratives have been shaped by victors, politics and cultural currents. But this is the tyranny of convenience. At its most vital, historical romance also resurrects ephemeral yet utterly timeless truths: the sensations of the body beneath the clothing, the agonizing decision to burn letters brimming with illicit love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 413, July 28, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Who Is Responsible for Fixing Condo Defects?
description: Condo boards have a duty to act in the interest of all unit owners. But if the board is controlled by the building’s sponsor, that could be tricky.
content: Q: We live in a newly constructed condominium in Manhattan. Last summer, we noticed dampness in the apartment and bought a humidity sensor that indicated the humidity in the unit to be 70 percent. We communicated with the management company through the fall, and they did some investigating, but the problem persists. We have installed a dehumidifier, but it’s loud and the reservoir needs to be emptied several times a day. What length of time is reasonable for the management company to address this? What else can we do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel, Chang W. Lee and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: Katie Ledecky’s relentless march toward history begins with a bronze in Paris.
description: Ledecky won her 11th Olympic medal, but was outpaced by Ariarne Titmus of Australia.
content: Barring a shortage of chlorine in Paris, Katie Ledecky is likely to become the most decorated female swimmer in Olympic history at some point over the next two weeks, a distinction that has been suffused the last decade with all the suspense of a rom-com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivienne Walt and Sarah Kessler
title: Why Is It So Hard for Olympic Host Cities to Control Costs?
description: An Oxford study estimates that despite cost-cutting efforts, Paris is spending more than $1 billion above the Games’ historical median cost.
content: Like every city that hosts the Olympics, Paris designed its opening ceremony to make a splash, with ethereal dance performances, athletes floating down the Seine and a blowout performance by Celine Dion. A big display is table stakes, and hundreds of thousands of people jammed the city’s bridges and riverbanks for hours to cheer the flotilla.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 24 Hours at the Golden Apple
description: We document one day in a Chicago diner called the Golden Apple, starting at 5 a.m. and going until 5 a.m. the next morning.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Alanis Morissette Is Not Aloof
description: Celebrating the 25th anniversary of her second album, the singer and songwriter spoke about being destabilized by sudden fame — and how she got her center back.
content: If Alanis Morissette’s albums were children, “Jagged Little Pill” would be the spoiled one — universally beloved, lavishly celebrated, extravagantly fed. She has a soft spot for her second born, “Supposed Former Infatuation Junkie,” which was reissued with new material last month for its 25th anniversary. (She plays from the album on her current tour, which has dates through September.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korea Reports Leak From Its Military Intelligence Command
description: It’s highly unusual for the nation’s authorities to publicly acknowledge a leak from the command​, which is one of South Korea’s top two spy agencies.
content: South Korea was investigating a leak from its top military intelligence command​ that ​local news media said had caused a large amount of sensitive information, including personal data on the command’s agents abroad, to end up in North Korea, its military said Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Saif Hasnat
title: ‘All We Think of Is Him’: Putting Names and Faces to Bangladesh Carnage
description: The partial lifting of a communications blackout is providing a picture of the young victims of a brutal crackdown on protesters. Thousands of others have been swept into jails.
content: A part-time tutor, shot in the neck and killed. A journalist and young father, felled by a bullet to the head. A shopkeeper’s son, also fatally shot in the head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: The Right-Wing Dream of ‘Self-Deportation’
description: Some conservatives have a grim proposal to make undocumented immigrants leave: Exclude their children from schools.
content: In his presidential campaign, Donald Trump has doubled down on bashing migrants crossing the southern border. They are criminals who are “poisoning the blood of our country,” he says. The Republican National Convention was full of talk of surging “migrant crime,” even though such a rise does not exist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Sergey Ponomarev
title: Away From the War in Gaza, Another Palestinian Economy Is Wrecked
description: With the closure of checkpoints, Israeli Arabs cannot come to Jenin and Tulkarm to shop, and West Bank Palestinians cannot leave to work in Israel, cutting incomes and building militancy.
content: Less than three years ago, Wassif Frahat spent $3 million to open a lavish, two-story restaurant, the Ali Baba. With an impressive, pillared entryway, polished stone floors, glittering chandeliers and colorful frescoes on the high ceilings, the restaurant was his commitment to a better future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Blinken and a Top Chinese Official in Talks on U.S.-China Tensions
description: The U.S. secretary of state pressed China’s top foreign policy official on Beijing’s support for Russia’s efforts to rebuild its military industries during the Ukraine war.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken pressed his Chinese counterpart Saturday on areas of sharp disagreement between the two nations, including China’s support of Russia’s military industrial sector, the State Department said in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: JD Vance Hits Back at Jennifer Aniston, Defending ‘Childless Cat Ladies’ Remarks
description: The “Friends” actress, who has been open about her fertility struggles, recently criticized Mr. Vance’s 2021 comments on social media.
content: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, struck back at the “Friends” actress Jennifer Aniston after she criticized him for his past complaint that the nation was governed by “childless cat ladies,” including Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: A.I. May Save Us, or May Construct Viruses to Kill Us
description: Managing artificial intelligence without stifling it will be one of our biggest challenges as we adopt the most revolutionary technology since fire.
content: Here’s a bargain of the most horrifying kind: For less than $100,000, it may now be possible to use artificial intelligence to develop a virus that could kill millions of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: Pete Buttigieg Thinks the Trump Fever Could Break
description: The Democrat talks about the election vibe shift and what a Kamala Harris win would mean for both parties.
content: This past month has been one of the most consequential and dizzying periods in modern American politics. It began with President Biden’s disastrous debate in late June. Then came an assassination attempt against former President Trump. A week later, President Biden dropped out of the race and endorsed his vice president, Kamala Harris. And now Harris is already the de facto Democratic nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Three Members of the Nelons Gospel Group Are Killed in a Plane Crash
description: The band members were traveling on Friday to a performance when their plane crashed in Wyoming. Four others on board were killed.
content: Three members of the award-winning gospel band the Nelons and four other people on board were killed in a plane crash in rural Wyoming on Friday, according to the authorities and representatives for the band.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Rising Star of Surfing is at Peace, and on Roll
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 27, 2024.
content: “When you’re on the wave, you’re very free. It’s an open canvas.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Ada Petriczko
title: ‘No One to Talk To’: The Lingering Trauma of Russian Rape in Ukraine
description: Prosecutors in Ukraine are pursuing cases of sexual assault by Russian soldiers, but survivors say more financial and psychological support is needed.
content: After Daria fled from her Russian-occupied village to western Ukraine, she spent weeks restlessly wandering the streets. Whenever she grew tired of walking, she would sit on park benches and tell anyone who would listen — even perfect strangers — what the Russian soldiers did to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
title: New Israeli Evacuation Order in Gaza Displaces Palestinians Again
description: The order affected part of southern Gaza, while farther north, the Israeli military struck the grounds of a school it said was being used by Hamas, killing more than 30 people, Gaza officials said.
content: The Israeli army ordered the evacuation of several neighborhoods in southern Gaza on Saturday, the latest in a series of such directives recently that have forced tens of thousands of displaced Palestinians to relocate yet again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Despite Park Fire’s Rapid Spread, Some Residents Are Determined to Stay Put
description: In Butte County, Calif., some defied evacuation orders so they could protect their property from the fire that has quickly become the state’s largest this year.
content: As California’s biggest fire of the year raced toward his neighborhood and the police ordered residents to evacuate, Justin Freese decided he was going nowhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,135, Sunday, July 28, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: You See Rubble and Garbage. She Sees New York’s Next Great Park.
description: Rosa Chang devoted herself to repurposing nine ugly acres under the Brooklyn Bridge. Amazingly, nobody has said no yet.
content: The area under the Brooklyn Bridge in Lower Manhattan is a forbidding swath of rubble and construction equipment, cut off from the sky by six lanes of clattering bridge traffic. To most of the world, it communicates a single message: keep out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Peter Thiel, Elated by the JD Vance Pick, Warms to Trump Again
description: Mr. Thiel, the Silicon Valley billionaire, is coming around to Donald Trump’s candidacy again after bumps in their relationship. But he thinks his money wouldn’t really help Trump.
content: The Silicon Valley billionaire Peter Thiel’s relationship with Donald J. Trump turned ice-cold in the middle of 2023, when the former president excoriated Mr. Thiel on a private phone call over his unwillingness to support Mr. Trump’s re-election bid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Most Stylish Olympic Opening Ceremony Ever
description: Paris raised the fashion stakes for the XXXIII Olympiad, and even with the rain, the result transformed the Seine into a watery runway.
content: Even before the XXXIII Olympiad officially began, the litany of firsts was enormous. The first Olympics in Paris in a century. The first with equal gender participation. The first opening ceremony, ever, en pleine air. The first sponsored by a global luxury behemoth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Emily Schmall
title: Man Charged in Death Threats to Trump Trial Judge and Prosecutor
description: A judge ordered Spencer Gear into custody, citing threats to the district attorney and judge in New York days after Donald Trump’s conviction in his hush-money case.
content: A man in Las Vegas has been charged with threatening to assault and kill federal officials, judges and state employees across several states, according to a federal indictment, including at least two people involved in the prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tahir Duckett
title: The Police Killing of Sonya Massey Argues for Alternatives to Reform
description: Until we narrow the scope of what police officers can do, we’ll continue to see officers bring violence into situations that don’t require it.
content: On July 6, Sonya Massey called 911 to report an intruder. After Sean Grayson, a sheriff’s deputy, and another officer found no intruder outside of her home in Sangamon County, Ill., they knocked on her door. The situation escalated after Ms. Massey went to turn off her stove. Within seconds Mr. Grayson drew his gun and shot her in the head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Latino Leaders Set Aside Their Rocky Past With Kamala Harris on Immigration
description: Hispanic leaders and civil-rights groups are backing the vice president, despite their clashes with the Biden administration on border policy.
content: No issue is likely to be thornier on the campaign trail for Vice President Kamala Harris, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, than immigration. Republicans are falsely painting her as President Biden’s failed “border czar” and running ads tying her to Biden administration policies that they argue have contributed to chaos at the border.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 27, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Saturday, July 27, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Uneven Bars
description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Paris, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
content: For two weeks every four years, women’s gymnastics is one of the biggest sports in the world. The rest of the time, those of us watching are kind of a niche group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 5 Excerpts From JD Vance’s Emails to a Transgender Classmate
description: A former Yale Law School classmate shared with The Times about 90 emails and text messages with Mr. Vance. Here are some of the most revealing moments in their correspondence.
content: As Senator JD Vance seeks the vice presidency, a former Yale Law School classmate and friend has shared about 90 of their emails and text messages, mostly from 2014 through 2017, with The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Senter and Neil Vigdor
title: Minnesota’s Governor, a Harris V.P. Contender, Calls Trump and Vance ‘Weird People’
description: Gov. Tim Walz took jabs at Trump and his vice-presidential pick, JD Vance, at a rally in St. Cloud, Minn., hours before the Republican duo were scheduled to arrive for their own campaign event.
content: In a potential audition to be Kamala Harris’s running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota on Saturday cast former President Donald J. Trump and his vice-presidential pick, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, as a dangerous combination before their campaign visit to the state later in the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
title: More Trains, but Few Answers, After Railway Sabotage in France
description: France’s national railway company said traffic was gradually returning to normal a day after arsonists disrupted three high-speed rail lines. But who was behind the attacks remains mysterious.
content: In the dark early morning, they cut into a fence protecting the high-speed rail line right outside the small town of Croisilles. Once past the fence, the culprits soldered open the metal protective cover of a culvert alongside the tracks. Then, they poured flammable liquid and set a fire, damaging around 40 cables, explained the local mayor, Gérard Dué.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: JD Vance, Purr-fectly Dreadful
description: Women should bat JD around like a ball of twine.
content: Suddenly, Donald Trump looks enlightened about women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig, Alan Blinder and John Yoon
title: Park Fire in California Grows Dramatically, Becoming Largest Active Blaze in U.S.
description: The fire in Northern California has burned more than 350,000 acres. In Oregon, firefighters were working to contain the Durkee fire, which has covered at least 288,000 acres.
content: The Park fire in Northern California has grown considerably to become the largest active blaze in the country, as firefighters raced on Saturday to contain scores of blazes across the American West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Level, Essentially
description: You’ll need good balance to take on Barbara Lin and Matthew Stock’s collaboration.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Barbara Lin’s Saturday debut, and it’s an achievement: She has now “hit for the cycle” as a New York Times constructor, meaning that she has created at least one puzzle for every day of the week. Matthew Stock, who shares credit for today’s grid, has accomplished this feat as well. He’s a prolific collaborator, so it’s perfect that he joined Ms. Lin as she took on the challenge of making a Saturday grid, as detailed in their notes below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Ivis
title: Inside a Twister With the World’s Most Famous Storm Chaser
description: For a recent assignment, a photographer found herself taking images from inside a tornado.
content: Every storm chaser has been looking forward to seeing the movie “Twisters,” a loose follow-up to the box-office smash “Twister” from 1996.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Floor Exercise
description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Paris, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
content: For two weeks every four years, women’s gymnastics is one of the biggest sports in the world. The rest of the time, those of us watching are kind of a niche group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: JD Vance, an Unlikely Friendship and Why It Ended
description: His political views differed from a transgender classmate’s, but they forged a bond that lasted a decade — until Mr. Vance seemed to pivot, politically and personally.
content: When his book, “Hillbilly Elegy,” was published in 2016, JD Vance sent an email apologizing to a close friend from his Yale Law School days. The friend identified as transgender, but Mr. Vance referred to them in the book as a lesbian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump, Honing Attacks on Harris, Casts Her as a Far-Left Threat
description: Speaking to religious conservatives in Florida, former President Donald J. Trump accused Vice President Kamala Harris of wanting to use left-wing values to transform the United States.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump sharpened his attacks against Vice President Kamala Harris on Friday, accusing her of wanting to impose left-wing values on the nation, painting her as overly liberal on immigration and abortion and calling her a “bum” in a speech to a gathering of religious conservatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Balance Beam
description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Paris, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
content: For two weeks every four years, women’s gymnastics is one of the biggest sports in the world. The rest of the time, those of us watching are kind of a niche group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: I Was a Kamala Harris Skeptic. Here’s How I Got Coconut-Pilled.
description: Harris’s success and setbacks could make her the ideal candidate against a man who admits no mistakes, has no humility and is utterly unrelatable.
content: I remember the moment I knew that Kamala Harris was not the candidate for me in the 2020 presidential race. It was just a few days before the second Democratic primary debate, and college student debt had become an issue on the campaign trail. Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren were promising large-scale, no-strings-attached relief to borrowers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Kamala Harris Is Known Abroad for a Personal Touch, and Tough Talk
description: Heads of state and diplomats who have interacted with the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee say she uses humor, and talk of food, to help leaven hard discussions.
content: Like most vice presidents, Kamala Harris was not given much runway on foreign policy. President Biden prided himself on his international expertise and relished his rapport with global leaders. But in the role she did fill, Ms. Harris made an impression.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Reflecting on Biden’s Exit and His Legacy
description: Readers express their gratitude and frustration.
content: To the Editor:

title: Olympics Results
description: The latest medal count and results for the Paris Olympics.
content: The latest medal count and results for the Paris Olympics.

author: By Sandra Winther
title: A New Wave
description: Michael February, a boundary-breaking surfer and the first Black South African on the World Surf League Championship Tour, embarks on a transformative journey.
content: Michael February, a boundary-breaking surfer and the first Black South African on the World Surf League Championship Tour, embarks on a transformative journey.
